channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Raw Data: To Beat Go Champion, Google’s Program Needed a Human Army
item.description: Without the multitude of minds that created a program capable of beating a Go game master, the contest would have been a no-go.
item.dc:creator: GEORGE JOHNSON
item.media:description: Lee Se-dol, a professional Go player from South Korea, was smiling amid other players despite losing four of five games against a Google computer program called AlphaGo.

item.title: 2 Libyan Guantánamo Inmates Are Transferred to Senegal
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry reiterated the Obama administration’s arguments that the American military prison in Cuba should be closed.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Double Agent Kim Philby Bragged of How Easy Spying Was in 1981 Lecture
item.description: During the talk to members of the Stasi, recently discovered by the BBC, he described his successes and urged colleagues to “deny everything.”
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: False News From the Sisi State
item.description: As hundreds of young Egyptians continue to disappear, no one believes the government’s explanations.
item.dc:creator: MONA ELTAHAWY

item.title: Greece Begins Sending Migrants Back as E.U. Deal Takes Effect
item.description: No Syrians were present in the first group that arrived back in Turkey on Monday, Volkan Bozkir, the European affairs minister for Turkey, said.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: The authorities on the Greek island of Lesbos began deporting refugees to Turkey on Monday morning.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Could There Be a Terrorist Fukushima?
item.description: Nuclear facilities throughout the world are vulnerable to attack.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM ALLISON and WILLIAM H. TOBEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Xujun Eberlein on the Legacy of the Cultural Revolution
item.description: The writer considers the emotional complexity of reconstructing an era whose memories are painful to the victims and shameful to those who victimized.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Xu Ruodan, Xujun Eberlein’s sister, joined a Red Guard faction in Chongqing and drowned in 1968 trying to emulate Mao Zedong’s swim across the Yangtze River. This photograph, which shows Ms. Xu the week before her death, was provided by Ms. Eberlein.

item.title: Sinosphere: China News Blackout as ‘Ten Years’ Takes Hong Kong Best Film Award
item.description: The mainland state news media omitted mention of the film, which depicts a dystopian future for Hong Kong under Chinese rule.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Andrew Choi, center, the executive producer of “Ten Years,” with directors and cast members, after accepting the statuette for best film at the Hong Kong Film Awards on Sunday.

item.title: Memo From China: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
item.description: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Grave markers in a cemetery with smoke billowing behind them from a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi, China. Some scientists believe China’s emissions may be falling modestly, as its economy grows more slowly.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Politics of Backlash
item.description: Another two decades of neo-liberal, reward-the-rich politics will lead to a breakdown in society.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Chongqing Journal: Chaos of Cultural Revolution Echoes at a Lonely Cemetery, 50 Years Later
item.description: The tension between official silence and grass-roots remembrance is palpable at the last sizable resting place solely for victims of the Cultural Revolution.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The gates of a cemetery, typically closed to the public, in the Shapingba district of Chongqing, China. During the Cultural Revolution, the city was the site of bloody battles between rival Red Guards, and many of the dead are buried here.

item.title: Armies Used by U.N. Fail Watchdog Group’s Test
item.description: A new study found that the armed forces that provide the most United Nations peacekeepers are also among the world’s most susceptible to corruption.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Panama Law Firm’s Leaked Files Detail Offshore Accounts Tied to World Leaders
item.description: News media outlets said the documents revealed the accounts of 140 politicians, including figures with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: The documents revealed the offshore accounts of 140 politicians and public officials, including several individuals with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: China’s Companies Poised to Take Leap in Developing a Driverless Car
item.description: Conditions for the technology may actually be more favorable in China than in the United States because of aggressive support from the government.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF and PAUL MOZUR
item.media:description: A traffic jam in Shenzhen, China. Car ownership has spiked in China, and traffic problems plague its largest cities.

item.title: Third Man Is Charged in Belgium Over Foiled Plot in France
item.description: The 33-year-old Belgian was charged with participation in the activities of a terrorist group, the federal prosecutor’s office said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in Molenbeek watched as the police advanced toward anti-Islam protesters on Saturday.

item.title: Lost in Nicaragua, a Chinese Tycoon’s Canal Project
item.description: Sixteen months after ground was broken, a plan by a Chinese billionaire that would link the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and greatly alter a country is shrouded in mystery and controversy.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: In parts of Nicaragua, public images of President Daniel Ortega, including this one in Rivas, have been hit with black paint balls over his support for a canal project.

item.title: Overpass Project in Kolkata ‘Made Our Lives Hell’ for Years Before Collapse
item.description: Irritation with the faltering project, unfinished after seven years, has turned into a sort of focused hatred for the people who live beneath it.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Rescue workers cleared debris Friday during efforts to free people trapped under a collapsed highway in Kolkata.

item.title: Gato Barbieri, Latin Jazz Trailblazer With a Saxophone, Is Dead at 83
item.description: Mr. Barbieri, whose career began in Argentina in the 1940s, recorded dozens of albums and received a Latin Grammy lifetime award in 2015.
item.dc:creator: PETER KEEPNEWS and CHRISTOPHER MELE
item.media:description: Leandro Barbieri, known as Gato, playing the tenor saxophone at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan in 2001.

item.title: Insider’s Account of How Graft Fed Brazil’s Political Crisis
item.description: A leftist party led by Dilma Rousseff that rose to power vowing to stamp out the corruption of a privileged political elite ended up embracing its predecessors’ practices.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcídio do Amaral, a Brazilian senator, was arrested in November, accused of plotting to smuggle a convicted former executive of Petrobras, Brazil’s state-controlled oil company, out of the country.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Jacob Zuma Must Go
item.description: A court ruling that South Africa's president has abused his office should herald a new era of democratic accountability.
item.dc:creator: MARK GEVISSER
